values:
Palm leaves

at exactly 12:00 midnight
1973-74
Los Angeles
it began to rain on the
palm leaves outside my window
the horns and firecrackers
went off
and it thundered.

I'd gone to bed at 9 p.m.
turned out the lights
pulled up the covers -
their gaiety, their happiness,
their screams, their paper hats,
their automobiles, their women,
their amateur drunks...

New Year's Eve always terrifies
me

life knows nothing of years.

now the horns have stopped and
the firecrackers and the thunder...
it's all over in five minutes...
all I hear is the rain
on the palm leaves,
and I think,
I will never understand men,
but I have lived
it through.

(C. Bukowski)
I can watch this movie again and again.

Baaaaaaaah, who I dislike are those people:
Me: "Ok, let's state that we have different opinions about that. You're convinced A is the case and I'm convinced it's B. But we have to get that piece of work done, so what should we do now?"
Them: "No, I know I'm right, trust me, I'm right."

Finally I found the song I was searching for since about 1990: Psycho Killer (Talking Heads). The only hint I had was a memory of the OH OH OH OH, AY AY AY AY-Part. My Book is in print now and should be out next month. 3 German and 1 Swiss libraries pre-ordered it, I hope that's a good sign. Ah, and here's my latest little piece of art (if it's art). It's called "Stacking Jesus":
Merry Christmas everybody! Going back to the north tomorrow, leaving the big prussian city and looking forward to breathe some fresh sea air. What I desperately yearn for is this kind of landscape:
My latest find: Emil Cioran. He's a philosopher with a bukowskiesque attitude. I love them both. The humanity lurking inside the disillusion.

Hi, I'm a lazy blogger, in fact I'm not a blogger at all. You can follow my Soup instead. I'm busy with my book, first I have to write some marketing-suitable abstracts, then format it. I'll be published in January '10 or earlier. I'm also looking for a new job and hope to find some before my company gets bought or insolvent or I get fired. In 2,5 weeks there will be national elections. I'll surely vote for the pirate party, because I detest surveillance and and am very shocked about the step-by-step dismantling of of civil rights and our constitution by almost all of the other partys, our marvelous constitution which is a condensed lesson our country learned from 12 years of nazi dictatorship. (The very first article is the most important: "The dignity of man is inviolable. To respect and protect it is the duty of all state authority.") We'll see how much votes the'll get. You need to get 5% to enter the parliament.
I'm house hunting. Actually apartment-hunting. How boring. If I had more money I would pay someone to hunt for me.

Yesterday, The Killer came to town ;-) There were two bands playing before, one local band from Hamburg (including this guy) and some other with a girl on piano, who played good, but sang too decently. After 1,5 hours Jerry Lee entered the stage and performed about 10 songs. His vocal range may be reduced to one octave now, but his piano-playing is still surprisingly fast and accurate. Well, several times he speeded up the tempo a little bit - and the band followed him obidiently - but he has one skill that separates the wheat from the chaff: To know when to play what and to know how much and how sparse (<- booaaa, bad phrase). Especially in comparision to the two other bands who did'nt know how to create tension and relief and and what music that originated from blues is all about: You must not pay particularised and follow the chords while soloing. It's the tension between your tone and those three chords that makes your solo or fill-ins interesting. And its a matter of the dose of musical effects (e.g. the ongoing hammering on one tone) that make them effective. Jerry Lee Lewis still knows and knows how. Here's a little movie from the gallery: http://www.latent.de/Filme/JerryLee.mov

My dissertation is finally and at very last written and passed in. Phew!

Since 3 Weeks im in Berlin ... as an intern (at the age of 38 ;-D ) ... e-commerce ...
Berlin is a big and lively city, but: There are no seagulls.

My prediction:

1. The Bush-administration tries to nourish the Georgia-Russia-conflict until the election day so that people, feeling that a "tough guy" in foreign policy is needed, will vote for McCain.

2. Hillary expects McCain to win and plans to run again in 2012, when Barack is out of the race.

Watched War Games again. Though I've seen it many times it's still exciting me. That makes me realize that the atomosphere of the 80s is still in me somewhere, like: millionfold extinction is at the fingertips of two old men in east and west. Something that's beyond the imagination of those yuppie-kids from nowadays, who's only aim is to succeed and live life as it was a competition. Or a game, but it's... ... what means: Do not let them make you to accept that it's a game and about winning or loosing at all.
Big Hype here for Obama taking a speech in Berlin tomorrow. ... they said, 80% of Gemans would vote for him if they could .... me too ;-)
And I found a cassette on which I read a whole hour some of Grimm's Fairy Tales. I have no idea when and why I did that. Maybe for a girl???

I'm sorting out old cassettes. I used to record records on cassettes to preserve the records.

And found some old recordings ... me fiddling folk music in 1987 ...
I bought a bass recorder. Great fun.

So, been in Liverpool. It's a nice city (much nicer than Manchester where the our plane landed) - exept the surveillance overkill everywhere in England :-( After visting the Beatles-Museum at the docks we took a bus tour to see all the Beatles-related places. You got a good impression about the area where the grew up, the walk John had to take to visit Paul to write songs together, the bus line where Paul met George evey morning when riding to school, the hall Paul and John first met on a suburb-fest, the graveyard where Elenor Rigby is buried (they didn't let us go there...) and of course the atmosphere of the cavern club. Yeah (yeah, yeah), the cavern club (rebuilt with the stones from the original one) At the opposite side: Kitsch: George's Birthplace: Place of Pilgrimage 1 Where John Lennon lived as a boy: Where Paul lived as a boy and where John and Paul met, because John's Aunt didn't like music. About 100 Beatles-Songs were composed in the front room at the ground floor: Place of Pilgrimage 2 at the end of the road. The "Magical-Mystery-Tour"-bus didn't stop at the rotary where the barber was showing photographs and the nurse was selling poppies: Where Ringo lived as a boy: More Pictures or Liverpool are here if you click on February 28th to March 2nd
I'm going to visit Liverpool in two days. There's no question, I'll have to see the Cavern Club, Penny Lane and the Strawberry Fields.
So, Hitler painted that? True or not, the world is absurd anyway.
I know there are people deeply into handicrafts. I do sympathize with them. But ... what is the use of those absurd things? =:-o

Watched Themroc tonight. Michel Piccoli only grunting for 1:50 hours. He stopped living a monotonously life as a working man and started to live as a cave man. It's up to the viewer to decide wheter this is a regress or progress. Next movie on my harddrive waiting to be watched: The Cars that ate Paris. =8-) And I got CTS on both hands. Nice.

I got a new Passport, it was the last chance to get one without fingerprints. It's valid for 10 years, so nobody will get my fingerprints until 2017 - unless I want to visit the U.S.

I'm no criminal and don't want to be treated as one.

I'm not dead or missing. I'm just busy with writing my PhD-stuff, which should be finished by the end of the year. So my motivation for writing things down here is quite low, because I'm trying to write things down on most of my days. Anyway, news from me - not written, but photographed or filmed - can always be received on this feed: feed://www.latent.de/feed.xml You don't have to understand German, just click on the links. Meanwhile, this is Marx (sitting), Engels (standing) and me (lying):
I heard today that a second life avatar consumes more electric power than a Brazilian.

Digital? What do you mean by "there's digital"? Mixing the developer Cooling it down to 20 degrees Celsius Things are prepared for complete darkness Ready to develop I had a b/w film I shot in 2002 in New Mexico that was still undeveloped. There were pictures of a tarantula on it that crossed my way.

I watched The Day of the Triffids. That was great fun, those silly plants walking like an army of idiots... The only reason I did was because there is an allusion in the title song of RHPS "fight a triffid that spits poison and kills". Now I have to find out what's meant by "Leo G. Carroll was over a barrel when the Tarantula took the hills." ;-)
Who needs a mixer? (click to watch)
Two that don't match: Clap, clap, clap

In the (late) 80s I thought I was born too late, because I did not experience the cool 70s consciously outside my little child's world. When I took a nap this afternoon and was dawning into sleep a picture came back, me riding the bus in San Francisco from the airport to downtown in summer 1989. A very special feeling was connected with that remembrance, something I can't describe in words, but it was kind of light-hearted and all-possibilities-there-for-me, without fear of the future. And being away from home but not feeling away from home. Today I think the late 80s weren't that uncool and pity those young people who didn't experience that time. Pre-terror, pre-climate-change, pre-internet. (I still have a full shoebox of letters (yes, handwritten letters) from my early loves and I plan to take them with me to the old people's home. I won't take any E-mails or IM-chats with me.) [every christmas when they play "last christmas" on MTV, look at those ridiculous clothes they wear - that was the time I finished 'high school'] WW2-bunker Guess who ate that book

Got a new and faster DSL-connection ("Alice Deluxe" ;-) ) and it's fun. The worrying part is that I noticed again how the online-life has become a part of my own. Because of an error I was without the internet for one and a half day. And I felt like someone murdered my beloved pet. Now that most things are faster I feel like I made a progress myself, like I achieved something I could be proud of. What the hell. If some trees load faster in Second Life it makes me happy. If a video-stream is smoother I feel more capable. When I come home and there is no internet I feel like some burglar took away my cozy furniture. That's Web 3.0 - the internet is a part of our souls. Haha: 50's hot design: No party without some idiot full of drugs falling on the floor: Some ORIGINAL FAT of Joseph Beuys: (...and cheese)

Other unimportant news: I found a luxembourg-1-cent-Euro-coin in my purse today. You might know that Euros have one identical side and one that's nation-specific. It's a game among us to collect the "foreign" Euro-coins that make their way into our purses - buying them at a coin-collectors-shop isn't allowed.
Luxembourg is a very tiny nation (1000 square miles) with 475.000 citizens (The city I live in has 1.745.000), so it's not very likely to find their coins in your purse and the 1-cent-coin is the rarest.
So I'm stupidly glad.

You know, I'm a fan of the long s, everytime I see one I am happy: How can they know how a Dinosaur's back did look like? Old Hamburg, my pumpkin-curry and deutsche Gründlichkeit (Coffee samples in a roastery) We had 4 very good (and too much different) wines that evening (mine is the one on the left, the rule is: everyone brings a bottle along he likes) - after a couple of hours my tounge was numb Inside a "Session Box"

Life-insight #1: Everything I do, I do slower that others. I need more time to accompish things at a level I strive for, but I do - just at my own pace. Years are nothing to me. When people estimate me they mostly characterize me as an unhurried and calm person. But firstly: The fewest can understand that someone can be ambitious and lazy at the same time, and secondly: the fewest can imagine calmness as a strategy to counter stress situations or constellations. Life-insight #2: Since ever and for ever on I avoid competitious situations. Let there be a contest, a race for anything and I'll be gone. The slightest awareness of the chance to be measured in any scale evokes a shortening reaction. I even despise people who willingly fit themselves in into a competition. And when I can't avoid competition, I unconsciously boycott it by acting in an way that makes me fall out of the pattern for sure. Life-insight #3: My life is a good one altogether.

Kabelbrand! This happens when I do wiring: Lübeck: Inside a church: Windspiele:      
(click pics to watch)

Been a week on Lanzarote. An overdue time out. I enjoyed the moonlike landscape very much. No I have to befriend with the damp, cold, but green one here again. Me standing on lava:
(click to watch) (Big file - but I can't stand stuttering water at 15 frames/sec and blurred texture of the stones)

The landscape that makes me feel home: After 4 years my beloved Clarks Desert Boots are finally done. (click to watch) Old and new: Harbour is always nice: Boring suits mostly contain boring people - or not? Numbers and algae
Didn't know that it's so easy... How to Hack a Diebold Voting Machine Thanks god we still have to draw big crosses into big circles here.

Spelling is difficult, Donald Dack. Moving house / the zigzag thing in the front is a coffin moving device / fat food for hard working men Nice chair / an albino Duck with it's chicks Numbered / the storm Covered lanterns / I didn't read so I tried to pass the wall Noone can steal my old data now

Finally I replaced the HD with a new (and bigger) one and managed to copy-clone all the data to the new. A lot of screwing tiny screws. (click to watch) Now I'm busy catching up two weeks of 21st century communication outage (which ist actually more consuming than communicating).

Last Friday my internal Harddrive got stuck. And I kind of freaked out, because I hadn't backed up my important data lately (except the very important data like my PhD-scripts - I'm stupid, but not that stupid). My laptop didn't boot, nothing, even booting from a DVD didn't work, only strange sounds from the HD. The next day I found out that if I lean the whole computer to the left or the right by turns I works with interruptions. So I was able to copy the important data to some other HD. Big relief. But now I'll have to wait until next Wednesday, when a friend comes with special equipment and we try to copy all the data including personal settings from the old to a new HD (a very few things have been easier before Macs got a Unix-System) I have no Computer at home and no Internet always at hand.

The only worrying thing about all that is, to what extent the computer and the internet became a part of my life: I almost felt like someone broke into my flat and stole half of my things. I felt partly helpless without the machine always running. Cut off from the world because my E-mails weren't checked every hour anymore and no new podcast coming in, no strolling through the usual sites, no editing of new photos and movies and no music downloading.

Addicted and committed, I'm a cyborg.
